name: wired
content:
wired adjective
(TECHNOLOGY)
Add to word list
Add to word list
connected to a computer or other device by a wire: All sorts of wired and wireless devices are now Internet-enabled. I had to rely on access to a wired network connection with my laptop, which sometimes involved a long wait. Compare
wireless adjective
using computers and the internet: A wired organization is potentially more open to change. In this digital age, children are born to be wired. We are now raising a wired generation.
More examplesFewer examplesA wireless alarm is harder to tamper with and easier to install than a traditional wired model.He had to plug in a wired headset in order to communicate while driving.a wired mouseYou can get schools wired but then they need continuing technical support.In today's wired global economy, the physical location of a company is less important.

wired adjective
(EXCITED)
informal, informal (UK also wired up) nervous or excited, for example because of a future event, or because you have drunk coffee or taken drugs: I was totally wired before the interview. I find that eating something can help if I'm too wired on caffeine. Sometimes, for no apparent reason, all the children may become wired up.
More examplesFewer examples We are totally wired about working with these new clients.Withdrawal symptoms include extreme anxiety, paranoia, brain fog and feeling wired.He was wired on amphetamines.
